definition: A2P means Assurance Prévention Protection, and is a certification for security standards attributed by CNPP, the National Center for Protection and Prevention, based in France. It's attributed to equipments and products of protection that were extensively tested, demonstrating superior protection and security. A2P norm includes a criteria of protection against intrusion, and a criteria of protection against fire. Lock cylinders can be classified from one to three stars, according to their resistance to a physical attack.

Acronym for "Association des Crocheteurs de France", the French Lockpickers Association, founded by enthusiasts of non-destructive entry. The Association promotes research and education in locksport, as well as championships.
Sidebar that has an active role in the locking mechanism, i.e., interacts with coding elements of the lock that must be picked.
Component at the back of the plug that throws the bolt or unlocks the shackle when the plug is turned.
A type of Fence lever control device which lifts the lever fence away from the cam with rotation and requires the operator to trigger the mechanism.
A spring loaded device which when the backplate removes, blocks the bolt with a lever. When the relocker is engaged, the lock will not open, even with the correct combination.

Keypins used in Medeco locks that have bottom of the true gate's groove capped off. They were made mainly to defeat the Medecoder, a tool that used the true gates groove as guide to decode the correct rotation of each keypin.
Acronym for All Wheels Left, indicating dialling all wheels CCW while taking readings.
Acronym for All Wheels Right, indicating dialling all wheels CW while taking readings.

Pin stacks where key pin and driver pin length are matched so that all stacks in the lock are roughly of equal height. Intended to reduce spring wear and make a lock resistant to decoding attacks that rely on knowing driver length.
Unshimmable mechanism in padlocks where ball bearings are pushed into the shackle to prevent opening.

Name given to driver pins with a shape similar to a “barrel”, having a portion near the extremities with a reduction in diameter, then flaring out at the end. Usually referring to the ASSA version, can also be used for other varieties like the DOM barrels.
Lock which can turn either clockwise or counter clockwise from the locked position to unlock the mechanism.
The part of a pin tumbler lock where the driver pins and springs reside.
Cover plate that is sometimes on top of the bible. Can usually be removed for [gutting](/#/glossary?term=gutting). Also called a spring cover.
The resistance to motion of an unset pin due to friction, usually against the sides of the bible chamber, when tensioning.
The unique cuts in a key that move tumblers to specified places when inserted.

An alphanumeric code that can be provided to a locksmith to cut a key to a desired shape. Some codes may be found on the keys themselves, other times on [security cards](/#/glossary?term=security%20card) that are obtained along with the lock.
The part of a pin tumbler / dimple key that enters the lock.
Picking a lock without foreknowledge of its pinning or bitting, picking without gutting or looking at the key beforehand.
A [rake](/#/glossary?term=rake), known for its unique design that mimics the peaks and valleys of a key. It's named after Bogotá, Colombia, where it was reportedly first created.
Acronym for [bottom of the keyway](/#/glossary?term=bottom%20of%20the%20keyway).
The nickname used for a tensioner used in the bottom of the keyway. Sometimes just called BOK.

Part of the locking mechanism that extends into the door frame to secure a door in place. In a typical lockset, the bolt is a metal bar that moves in and out of the door jamb, either by rotating a key or turning a knob or lever.

Also called "nipple pins" by some, it's a type of keypin with a thin cylindrical protrusion from the key contacting extremity. Mostly used by DOM, it's meant for increasing resistance to foil impressioning.

The area of the keyway opposite to the pins in a normal pin tumbler; corresponds to the inferior area of the keyway when the bible is upwards; in regular euro cylinder installation, with the bible downwards, will be the top part of the keyway.
The part of a key which is held, at the end of the blade/shaft.
To prevent a lock from functioning or gutting without physical damage. Dropping a driver pin in the plug is a common way to brick a lock.

Initials for "British Standard", from "British Standards Institution" (BSI), a ratings and standards organization that develops standards for locks and lock cylinders, based in United Kingdom. Present in the face or label of many locks (example: Yale Superior), the well known BSI [Kitemark](/#/glossary?term=kitemark) ("heart") logo identifies safety and security systems and devices that have been certified as meeting those standards of safety or security. In the case of lock cylinders they can be ranked either one or three stars. In some of the LPU ranked lever locks, BS in the model name identifies this certification.
A drive cam which is mechanically operated. It prevents testing the wheel pack unless the dial is correctly positioned and the cam mechanism is operated.

Discs from a disc detainer lock which have an internal profile with angled reliefs at the point of contact with the key, reducing the clockwise motion of the disc during operation. Used as a picking defence in Abus disc detainer locks to allow the front and rear discs to be operated by an uncut portion of key but will over rotate if used for tension.
Same as [snake rake](/#/glossary?term=snake%20rake).

In an LPU context, a lock made to secure the door of a cabinet by use of a bolt. Ranked cabinet locks are all [lever locks](/#/glossary?term=lever) of varying levels of security. Broader usage includes cam locks such as the ones used to secure file cabinets, etc.
The piece at the back of a plug that rotates with the movement of the plug. See [actuator](/#/glossary?term=actuator).
Consists of a cylindrical base and a rotating cam lever (the 'cam') attached to the base. When the key or tool is inserted and turned in the lock, the cam rotates, locking or unlocking the mechanism.
Lock modified from stock by a picker as a picking challenge to be passed around in the community.
Milled cyllindric-shaped hole where pins are inserted. Can be plug chambers or bible chambers.

Keypin that has been shaped with the key contacting extremity shaped like a wedge instead of a cone. Frequently used when correct keypin rotation is a requirement to open the lock (example: Medeco, Emhart), but can be also found in other locks without that feature (example: DOM system D).

A circlip, also known as a C-clip, is a type of fastener or retaining ring that consists of a semi-flexible metal ring with open ends. In locks, it is used to hold the [plug](/#/glossary?term=plug) in the [housing](/#/glossary?term=housing).
Rake profile that tries to emulate a key bitting, so that by wiggling it or jiggling it it might open a lock. Called so because of how it looks like a cityscape. Also called L-rake.
Acronym for [Challenge Lock](/#/glossary?term=challenge%20lock).
Tool used to overlift all pin stacks, opening some low-security locks.

Construction cores are locks used for temporarily controlling access for premises during construction. They usually work by including a special type of mastering where the mastering element (small wafer of ball bearing) will be removed from the lock chambers once the owner's key is used. Often present holes or large dimples next to the plug chambers, where the mastering element can drop into.
The position of the felt (or heard) point of contact between the lever nose and the lock mechanism (typically the cam). There are two contact points in a basic Group 2 dial (left, and right).

Some cylinders can both be opened in a regular way with an [operating key](/#/glossary?term=operating%20key), or opened with a [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key) to allow for the removal of the cylinder from the housing. Picking to control allows for the latter action. Most common in [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=sfic), but also in other types of locks.

Key that allows certain types of cylinders to be removed easily from the housing without fully disassembling the lock system, by causing a log to move or other similar locking element that keeps the cylinder in the housing. Most common in [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=sfic), but also in other types of locks.
Key used to remove a lock from its housing. Makes it easy to rekey a lock simply by swapping cores.

The term 'core' has two similar usages. It can be used to refer to the [plug](/#/glossary?term=plug) (the central part of a lock cylinder that turns) or to refer to the [cylinder](/#/glossary?term=cylinder) itself depending on the context.
The use of springs or similar to keep the plug at a neutral position.
Flat pieces of metal used for core shimming.
Regular cut in the chamber of a lock, widening the diameter in a portion of it. Sometimes refering to [undercut](/#/glossary?term=undercut%20milling) type of milling.
When in a [false set](/#/glossary?term=false%20set), and you push the element (usually a spool or false gate), causing the plug to rotate back against direction of tension.
To rotate the plug towards neutral from a false set. Can be caused by the lock elements, usually spools, or done manually. Sometimes written counter-rotation.
Shroud inside the lock which fits closely around the key and limits access to locking elements such as levers or discs.
A single part of the bitting to interface with a single element.
Lock that has been modified by removing metal so that one can see how it operates.

The lock body including the core/plug, the acuator, and the housing. Applies to locks that can be removed from their locking contexts such as door & knob installations as well as guttable padlocks. Common cylinder types include: rim, mortise, Euro-profile, KIK, and oval.
Screws onto the back of of the plug in some KIK cylinders to hold the plug in place. Very common in US residential cylinders.

Tool that facilitates the removal of the end cap from a KIK cylinder by depressing the cap retaining pin. Has notched ends to fit the shape of the grooves in the end cap, often with patterns to match several styles of cap.
Sprung pin that holds the cylinder cap in a fixed position, preventing the plug from coming loose.
Short for [disc blocker system](/#/glossary?term=disc%20blocker%20system).
Short for [Disc Detainer](/#/glossary?term=disc%20detainer).
Pick that has tensioner and tip rotating independently co-axially, used to pick disc detainer locks.

Pick profile with an offset shank, usually ending in a diamond style tip; in this case also called deforest (or DeForest) diamond or offset diamond. Named for its designer, Bill DeForrest, the name used by most manufacturers for this profile has since lost one of the 'r's. Deforest balls and gems exist also.
The height to which a specific part of the bitting is cut.
The part of a combination lock that is rotated.
To pick a lock with unsprung tumblers such as a disc detainer by moving tumblers directly to their correct position, mimicking the key.
The outer disc with the reference marking(s) for aligning the dial numbers.

An abbreviation of “different combinations", meaning the number of different keys that can be made for a specific model of lock. This will depend on the design of the key, the number of locking components, the number of available positions for each component, and the tolerances of the lock.

Generally used to identify a certain subtype of pin tumblers in which the coding is marked on the key mainly on the flat side; this distinction is useful from a tool choice perspective; although used to refer to the lock type itself, this isn’t technically correct, as the word “dimple” actually designates the round markings on the wide face of the key where the keypins make contact.
See [flag](/#/glossary?term=flag).
A lever fence which is integral to the lock boltwork; making the boltwork the fence. The wheel pack directly prevents the boltwork being retracted.
Often abbreviated to DBS. A system in disc detainer locks which locks the discs in position when tension is applied. Versions are included in Abloy Protec and Protec2, and Tokoz Pro.
Sometimes abbeviated to DC. Bars in the keyway of a disc detainer lock which center the key and restrict access for picking tools.
A type of lock that uses unsprung rotating discs and a sidebar. The key repositions the discs so that gates align, the sidebar drops into them and the plug can rotate.

Often abbreviated to DSS, consists of 2 half moon shaped sliders that interact with dimples on the key, retracting into them to allow for plug rotation. The inner nubs of these sliders restrict picking space, and the nubs in the outer edge will block the plug rotation unless the sliders drop properly in place.
Reffering to lever lock keys, one that has two sets of bittings from each side of the key shaft.
A cylinder that is in the centre of the keyway of a lever lock that uses a pipe key, reducing access and centering the key.

Components in a lock made of hardened steel to slow down or prevent drilling attacks. Various forms of drill protection are used by different manufacturers. They may be a part of the lock body itself, a steel pin or ball bearing inserted in the lock body or plug, or the pins themselves.
An extra wheel in (for example) a Group 2 lock that pulls the bolt mechanism, and raises the fence from the wheels to prevent feeling gates directly.

Pin that usually sits at shearline in a pin tumbler lock, preventing the rotation of the plug, positioned between a key pin and a spring. It must be fully lifted into the bible to open the lock. Also known as top pin when bible is upwards. Can include [security features](/#/glossary?term=security%20pin).
[Spool](/#/glossary?term=spool) driver pin comprising two separate pieces which can move independently. Named for the erratic feedback it provides to the picker.
See [disc steering system](/#/glossary?term=disc%20steering%20system).
A type of DOM pin, similar to a spool, but with an t-pin-like extension on each side, that is flared out at the tip. It's one of the "magic" DOM pins.
A small wheel mounted to the nose of the lever. Its purpose is to obscure the contact points.
Movable part of the locking mechanism preventing the lock from opening. See [tumbler](/#/glossary?term=tumbler).

A lock type common in Europe, sometimes referred to as simply 'euro'. A full version will have two functioning ends with either a keyway or knob. A 'half' euro-profile cylinder will only have a single side with a keyway. It is common locksport practice to cut a full euro cylinder in half to make two locks.
The visible part of a lock where the key is inserted.
Gates on a tumbler which are not deep enough for the core to turn if the sidebar falls in.
A portion of the wheel with a shallow cut designed to mimick a gate, that are not deep enough for the fence to drop completely.
The small rotation of a plug as elements (particularly spools or False gates) look partially set, that does not allow the lock to open.
The auditory, visual, and tactile sensations from a lock during picking.
The portion of the lever that slots into the wheels when the gate of the wheel directly faces it.
A device designed to only tension the lever fence against the wheel pack within a specific range on the dial. La Gard 3332 shown as example.
See [rotating fingerpin](/#/glossary?term=rotating%20fingerpin).
A disc in a DD that can't be turned, fixed in place.
Simple peg that "catches" the next wheel, mostly seen on older or cheaper locks.
Lock pick used for dimple locks, shaped like a rod with a protrusion at the side of the tip. Also called dimple pick.
Key made out of flat sheet metal. Also called plate key.

A special technique for picking pin tumblers where the picker completely controls the plug movement. This allows for careful manual counterrotation, for instance, to set a gin spool from the countermilling without dropping other pins. Can be done using one very well fitting tensioner, or two tensioners.
The linkage between wheels, a simple version would be a peg protruding which catches a peg on the next wheel.
See [plug follower](/#/glossary?term=plug%20follower).
A zone in which the last number of the combination must not be set to, as it can cause a mechanical malfunction.
Keypins that have been shaped with a forked extremity where they contacts the key. This is usually to make mastering easier without the addition of mastering wafers.
A lever fence that is pressed towards the wheel pack via friction. With this type of lever fence the wheel pack is only tested when the dial is rotated CCW and thus only gives one contact point.
Levers with rollers to add friction/noise to mask feedback from the nose to cam interaction. As found on Chubb Manifoil safe locks.

A piece of lock disassembly and reassembly equipment, rarely seen as a commercial tool, that allows for carefully removing and resetting pins in the the bible chambers of a full euro profile cylinder from the front. It includes a groove that will travel over the different chambers as you rotate the piece.
A disc detainer lock that can be front tensioned can be picked while tensioned from the front disc.
Dial is read from the face of the dial (parallel with spindle orientation).
A disc detainer lock that can be front or rear tensioned can be picked while tensioned from either the front or rearmost disc.

Acronym for Full Size Interchangeable Core. Similar to LFIC, it's a type of lock that can be removed from its housing with one key, and opened with another, called the [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key). Unlike [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=SFIC), neither [LFIC](/#/glossary?term=LFIC) or FSIC are a universal formats. While in most LFIC's the control key lifts the pins to a second shear line, FSIC control key is usually longer and has an extra cut, that interacts with the last pin controling the holding bar or pin. See also [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=SFIC) and [LFIC](/#/glossary?term=LFIC).
A divot on a slider or disc that allows the sidebar to fall into it.
The portion of the wheel cut to allow the fence to fall in.

Spools that have a thinner lip at one end than at the other, usually to interact with countermilling. So called because they loosely resemble a gin bottle. Also called gin bottle spool, gin spool or just gin.
Spools with a gradual taper in diameter reducing from the ends to the center. Also known as hourglass spools.
A lever fence that is pressed towards the wheel pack via gravity.
To tap and insert grub/set screws into the top of a bible, acting as individual bible covers for each chamber.
Tool used to remove circlips from locks during disassembling. Can be used as a general name for any tool with that function, although it usually refers to the one designed by Lock Noob.
To non-destructively disassemble a lock into its individual parts.
Pick profile where the tip looks like a triangle: one side sits flat along the end of the shaft, and the free point is used for picking.

Hardware device used for securing doors, lids, or gates. It consists of two main parts: a hinged metal plate (the hasp) and a looped metal strip (the staple). The hasp is attached to a fixed surface and folds over the looped staple, which is mounted on a movable part (like a door).
Although the use can be flexible, one acceptable definition is: a lock with 8 or more active and independent pin stacks, from at least 2 different rows from different directions.
Element in [FSICs](/#/glossary?term=FSIC) and some [LFICs](/#/glossary?term=LFIC) that hold the lock cylinder inside the housing.
Tool used for single pin picking, shaped like a thin flat metal bar with a raised hook at the end to lift pins.
Spools with a gradual taper in diameter reducing from the ends to the center. Also known as graduated spools.
The part of a lock the plug is placed into, containing the bible.
Acronym for [high pin count](/#/glossary?term=high%20pin%20count). Also a well-established brand of picks sold mainly in the United States.
A method for creating a key without gutting or picking, using binding and jiggle tests and a file.
Rotating the wheel pack is done via intermediary gears. Implemented to make manipulation more difficult.

Refers to elements on the lock that interact with moving elements on the key. These, in turn, sometimes interact with fixed or moving elements of the plug, to elevate the interactive element to shearline. Other times, the key itself may have the mechanism necessary for this interaction to happen, eg: an internal spring.
Famously present in Emhart locks, interlocking pins are attached to each other via dovetail connections, only dettaching at shearline with the correct lift and rotation by the key.
The allowed motion of a set element due to lock tolerances. See [Jiggle Test](/#/glossary?term=jiggle%20test).
A test to see whether an element is set or not by seeing if it has a small jiggle to it, corresponding to the spring movement. If there is none, it is binding or under/overset.

Tools that are meant to emulate different types of bitting, usually for water locks, and to be used as a key. The user will try to jiggle various of these jigglers inside a lock in turn until they get the lock opened.
Key that has not yet been cut to any specific bitting.
Insert a warded combo change key through all the wheels with gates aligned at the change index. Turn key, dial new combination at change index, turn key back and remove.
See [bitting code](/#/glossary?term=bitting%20code).

Tool used to determine the key cut depths on a key. The gauge has a series of notches or slots, each corresponding to different key cut depths, allowing one to measure and match these depths accurately.

Pin in the plug in a pin tumbler lock, that is lifted by the key to position the driver pin. Their length corresponds to the code for a key cut. When a key with the correct cut size in that position is inserted, the keypin lifts the driver pin just above the shear line. Also known as bottom pin when the bible is upwards. Can include [security features](/#/glossary?term=security%20pin).
The cavity in which the key is placed.
Short for Key in Knob cylinder, a type of cylinder often placed in knobsets or padlocks.

Present in the face or label of many locks (example: Yale Superior), the well known [BSI](#/glossary?term=BS) certification Kitemark ("heart" logo) identifies safety and security systems and devices that have been certified as meeting those standards of safety or security. In the case of lock cylinders they can be ranked one star (protection against physical attack, key security, fire resistance, durability, plug extraction, and lock bumping) or three stars (additional snap protection).
Same as [city rake](/#/glossary?term=city%20rake).
Padlock constructed from multiple layers of metal plates, usually steel, laminated and riveted together. The laminated lock body contains a traditional core, locking mechanism, and shackle.

Coding element shaped like a flat piece of metal, that rotates about one point, interacting with the locking elements, which can be, for example. a sidebar or a talon, depending on the type of lever lock. (2) Type of lock that uses levers as locking mechanism. The levers generally interact with a talon, an extended piece of metal of the bolt, usually through gates. When levers are lifted to the right height, the key pulls the bolt's talon into the levers' gates. (3) Italian levers (and silmilar types) are technically not levers as they don't rotate about one point, but are traditionally called levers.
A lever pivoting directly on the bolt having a fence mounted to it, usually pulling directly on the locking bolt to unlock.
A term for all the levers in a given lock.
A tool used to pick levers, either similar to a disc detainer pick or an L shaped wire.

Type of locking mechanism where levers interact with a sidebar, generally through gates, instead of a talon, allowing the sidebar to drop into the gates when the correct key is inserted and the plug to rotate

Acronym for Large Format Interchangeable Core. A type of lock that can be removed from its housing with one key, and opened with another, called the [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key). This key's action usually lifts the pins to a second shear line, allowing for the retraction of the holding pin or bar. See also [FSIC](/#/glossary?term=FSIC) and the smaller [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=SFIC)
Acronym for Locked On By Combination. Backplate cannot be removed without the proper combination.
I hope you know what this means.
A set of elements inside the lock that prevent it from being opened without the insertion of the correct key.
Lock Out Tag Out locks, used for maintenance work and safety applications. Should NEVER be picked in the field, are often inexpensive.

Maximum Adjacent Cut Specification. A rule for maximum height difference between adjacent bitting heights on a key. These vary with each lock model. Violation of MACS does not result in an unusable lock but does increase probablility that the key will not work properly in the lock.

General colloquial term for driver pins that are frequently found in modern DOM locks. They are so called because they are harder to pick than their shape suggests. They include DOM barrels, spools with widening ends, and the so called dumbbells, a type of t-spool (mix of spool with t-pin extremities) with flared out ends.
A Standard format for safe locks implemented originally by Sargent and Greenleaf.
Ferromagnetic pins or magnetized pins in a lock, or that are subject to a magnet placed on the key.
Ferromagnetic rotors or magnetized rotors in a lock, or that are subject to a magnet placed on the key. See [rotors(/#/glossary?term=rotors).
Ferromagnetic rotors or magnetized rotors in a lock, or that are subject to a magnet placed on the key. See [slider(/#/glossary?term=slider).
A unique mechanism similar to SFIC, but allowing 2 unique control keys instead of a control and operating key.
Very thin pins used to facilitate mastering in pin tumbler locks.
Adding (or removing) components within a lock to allow more than 1 unique key to work in the same lock.
Inner and outer wheels with a toothed mesh between them, pop them apart and turn them to desired combo, reassemble.
A lock cylinder that is designed to screw into a mortise lock. (2) A lock designed to fit in a pocket —- the mortise -—  cut in the door edge. Also called mortice (UK).
Flies that have some rotational freedom, to allow use of the whole range of each wheel.
A cam wheel that accepts a spline key in more than one position, to allow the drop-in area to remain at the same index point while orienting the lock body in.
Describes a single lock that employs more than one type of locking element, such as a combination of a pin tumblers and side pins, enhancing its resistance to picking.
Security driver pin that tapers from a regular cylinder with a wider, spool-like end. Named based on the visual similarity to a mushroom and cap.
A type of wire used in pianos, that is a good material to construct lever lock picks and similar tools.
Another name for [bottlenose pins](/#/glossary?term=bottlenose%20pins)
The portion of the lever that rests on the cam wheel.
See [DeForest(/#/glossary?term=deforest).
A keyway that has little or no significant warding in the direction of the middle line. Not [paracentric](/#/glossary?term=paracentric)

Some cylinders can both be opened in a regular way with an [operating key](/#/glossary?term=operating%20key), or opened with a [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key) to allow for the removal of the cylinder from the housing. Picking to operating allows for the latter action, generally responsible for the normal function of the lock. Most common in [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=sfic), but also in other types of locks.
A key used to turn the plug. Only used when a control key also exists.

Some cylinders can both be opened in a regular way, or opened to allow for the removal of the cylinder from the housing. The [operating key](/#/glossary?term=operating%20key) allows for the former action, generally responsible for the normal function of the lock, while the latter action will require a [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key). Most common in [SFIC](/#/glossary?term=sfic), but also in other types of locks.
Stacks of pins that directly oppose and are pushed by the main stacks of pins, and because of their weaker springs, some of them may be in a resting overset position.
A lock housing that has oval cross-section.
Regular cut in the chamber of a lock, widening the diameter at the shear line.
To lift an element too far past where it needs to be, preventing the lock from opening.
A portable lock with a [shackle](/#/glossary?term=shackle) that may be passed through an opening such as a chain link or [hasp](/#/glossary?term=hasp) staple.

A paracentric keyway is a security feature, most commonly seen in european and australian pin tumblers, in which the warding in the keyway protrudes past the vertical centerline of the keyway. The goal of this feature is to reduce the space available for inserting a picking tool and moving it in a way that allows the elements to be picked.
Technique used to isolate contact point readings to a single wheel.
Denotes a lock which is difficult to fully disassemble and can be used in a belt request without documentation of full gutting.
A pin that doesn't have a coding role in the lock and doesn't need to be picked to open the lock. Generally used for key control.
A sidebar that does not interact with coding elements of the lock needing to be picked. Usually related with key control function.
Picking this lock may risk damaging the lock in some way. Check the notes for the entry for details.
Pin used for the fly is put in one of a series of holes around the wheel circumference, changing the fly's position changes the combination number for that wheel.
A key for a lever lock where the shaft of the key is a solid cylinder. Also sometimes called a barrel key.
The combined key pin, driver pin, and spring within 1 chamber.
A key or driver pin that has a smaller pin inside that moves independently.

Any lock using stacks of pins composed by a coding keypin and a driver pin. Although generally used for locks with vertical keyways with pins coming from the bible side, and opened with vertical keys coded on one edge, the group technically includes also the so-called dimple locks and some tubular pump locks.

A piece of lock disassembling equipment especially used for gutting double euro profile cylinders. It is used to hold the drivers and springs inside the bible while the plug is removed or inserted in the lock body. It can be used for Euro and oval cylinders.
A tray where one can organize the elements of a disassembled lock. Makes it easier to showcase the components and to make sure they are not lost.

Tweezers are used for removing the small elements from a lock and reassembling it. In many cases, pinning tweezers are made or modified to make it easier to grab and secure pins, for example, with a groove near the tip.
Acronym for [pin-in-pin](/#/glossary?term=pin-in-pin).
A lever key with hollow cylindrical shaft, to interface with a drill pin.
A [flat steel key](/#/glossary?term=flat%20steel%20key).

That's a really interesting question. The fact of the matter is that the question itself is very interesting. Is it a plongus, or to plongus? Or do plongus plongus? Before we get stuck in the superficial meaning of plongus, we might want to deep dive into the philosophical issue of how plongus came to be. But that might be a matter for another day.

The central part of a lock cylinder that rotates when all locking elements are aligned properly to open the lock -- either by inserting a key into the plug or by picking the lock. The plug contains lock elements that directly contact the key, such as key pins and sliders. Also sometimes referred to as the [core](/#/glossary?term=core).
A long cylinder used to push the plug out when disassembling a lock, holding the driver pins in place inside the bible. Often just called 'follower'.
The use of circlips or similar to prevent a plug from falling out by itself or when pulled.
Acronym for [progressive pinning](/#/glossary?term=progressive%20pinning).
Simple tool used for manipulating and testing lock components. Can be used to open inexpensive [cam locks](/#/glossary?term=cam%20locks) and padlocks by directly moving the locking pawl.
The cross-sectional shape of a key or keyway.
Discs which have additional material in the keyway to restrict access for unauthorised key profiles or picking tools.
Colloquial for [progressive pinning](/#/glossary?term=progressive%20pinning).
Learning how to open a lock by removing tumblers, slowly replacing them as you pick until fully pinned.
Tool generally used for TOK tensioning.
See [push](/#/glossary?term=push).

A push lock, often called pump lock is a type of lock that tensions and opens by first pushing the key into the face of the lock before rotating. This includes, for example, most tubular locks (many of which are also types of pin tumblers), but also other locks that use sliders and sidebars as locking elements.
A tool that opens basic pin tumbler locks by random motion.
A disc detainer lock that is random mid tensioned can be picked while tensioned from an unknown disc  (not the front or rear disc)

One enters the "rattle club" by purposefully or, most commonly, accidentally, turning a Masterlock 410 LOTO's core 180º, or enough so that the keypins drop from the lock body into the inside of the plastic housing of the padlock. Because the keypins are now freely jiggling inside a mostly empty padlock body, you can listen to the rattling noise they make as you wiggle it around. It is said the padlock has turned into a rattle.
A type of driver pin usually found on some DOM locks, that consists on a thin spool-type element, featuring variable number of loose discs between the top and bottom sections
To tension a disc detainer or similar lock by reaching in with a tool and turning an element at the back of the lock.
A pair of bars in a bi-directional disc detainer lock which limit the rotation and return the discs to a neutral position as the lock is relocked
Sidebar that is spring biased into the plug with weaker springs than the sliders, preventing setting and feedback.
Cylinder similar to a mortise cylinder to be installed directly in a door, with the use of screws.
Said of a cylinder inside a padlock body, where the tolerances between them are so bad that the cylinder wobbles inside the padlock. Typical of Master Lock DG.

A fence looking much like a wing nut with a gear mounted to it. The gear is not fused to the fence but can turn independantly but with some friction. Also known as a [Friction fence](/#/glossary?term=Friction%20Fence).

Subtype of sidepin with extended prong that interacts with the key, with rotational as well as vertical lift coding (must be lifted and rotated). Generally associated to a sidebar. Also called simply fingerpin.
Keypins that have gates that interact with a sidebar, rotating to the true gate when the correct key is inserted.

Generally rounded or disc-like elements featuring a prong to interact with the key, another part of it interacting with another locking mechanism, like a sidebar. As the key is inserted, the prong moves along a laser cut track rotating the disc to the correct position to drop the sidebar into the gate.

Known in LPU as the act of accidentally removing an unretained plug of a lock from the body while trying to remove the key, consequently causing pins and springs to jump everywhere. Was made infamous by the talented lockpicker Culper, who accidentally gutted an ASSA on video in this way. Video that was turned into a frequently used gif.

Lock made to secure the door of a safe by use of a bolt. LPU uses the term 'safe lock' to distinguish a certain class of [lever lock](/#/glossary?term=lever) while other locks -- including dial locks which use gated wheels -- are common in safes as well.
An upright mortice lock, consisting of a latch bolt and a key operated bolt.
Acronym for Security Cylinder Drill-proof, a type of ASSA produced hardened steel cylinder. The letters are usually stamped on the face of such cylinders.

The Security Construction and Equipment Committee (SCEC) is a standing interdepartmental committee responsible for the evaluation and endorsement of security equipment for use by Australian Commonwealth departments and agencies. Under SCEC rating different certifications are issued to locking systems, being approved for areas of different threat levels.

Form of identification issued with certain high-security locks, required for making duplicate keys. It provides an additional layer of security by ensuring that only authorized individuals can have keys replicated.

Specialized pin used in lock cylinders to increase resistance to picking and manipulation, often featuring unusual shapes or mechanisms like spool, serrated, or mushroom designs. These pins make the lock more secure by creating an irregular path that challenges conventional lock-picking techniques.

Used for gutting double euro profile cylinders, the are sections of plug follower inserted from the rear of the lock cylinder, after removing the cam. Using them to push the plug out the front, one can keep the driver pins in the bible.
A type of pin or other element that has shallow grooves etched into it, causing confusing feedback.
Core modification of threading the chambers in the plug in order to catch the edge of spool pins. Creates misleading feedback for the picker.
To lift an element to its required position for the lock to open, and for it to stay there due to tension.

Acronym for Small Format Interchangeable Core. A type of lock that opens with one key and can be removed from its housing with another, called the [control key](/#/glossary?term=control%20key). See also [LFIC](/#/glossary?term=LFIC) and [FSIC](/#/glossary?term=FSIC)
The usually hardened steel part of a padlock that secures a chain or similar.
The cylindrical part of a lever lock key where the bitting flag attaches.
The part of a hook, rake, or other pick between the tip and handle.
Keypins that have been shaped with a thin flat vertical tip, similar to a shark fin, where they contact the key. This is usually to prevent foil impressioning in dimple locks.
A line representing the height to which pins must be lifted for the lock to open.

To insert a thin piece of metal (shim) between the plug and the housing. Generally used in locksport to prevent the driver pins to drop into holes in the plug that might brick the lock during disassembling. Can also be used to open and disassemble an unkeyed lock, by sliping the shim between the keypin and driver pin on every chamber from the back of the lock, while lifting each stack with a pick. In rare cases, one can shim a padlock from the front to open it.
To insert a shim between the shackle and body of a padlock without ball bearing mechanism, opening the lock without picking.
The part of a key near the bow that collides with the face of the lock to prevent over-insertion.

Small, movable cover or barrier that protects the keyhole or locking mechanism from external elements, such as dirt, dust, and moisture. The shutter is especially common in outdoor locks, like padlocks or automotive locks.
Piece of metal that interfaces with another locking element (eg. levers, sliders, other sidepins) and blocks rotation until the key is inserted.

Pin or pin-like elements that work as a secondary locking mechanism. Can include various pin types like fingerpins, sliders, active and passive pin elements, among others with no specific designation.
Reffering to lever lock keys, one that has only one set of bittings from one side of the key shaft.
Picking a lock by moving one element at a time under tension.
Lock cylinder design where portions of the cylinder's material are removed or cut away, leaving a more open or 'skeleton-like' structure. Common in cheap locks, as a way to save money on material.

The Dutch organization Quality Foundation for Facade construction (SKG) approves & rates locks on strength and durability. It is notable that SKG rating only involves destructive entry, not picking. In short, the rating definitions are 1 star: not able to provide three minutes of resistance on its own. 2 stars: at least three minutes of resistance. 3 stars: at least five minutes of resistance.
Core featuring a partial or complete sleeve around it, fixed or with limited movement, usually metallic, that will interact with the tumblers of the lock.

Element that moves in only one direction in the lock, usually without pushing directly other pins or elements, and is kept rotationally locked to maintain correct contact with the functional elements it interacts with. It can be the main or secondary locking mechanism of a lock. Can be Sprung or Unsprung. Generally considered only for those that interact with a sidebar, although the actual definition and distinction with Wafers is controversial.

Specialized pick, generaly custom made from a blank or broken pick, with the tip shaped like a two prong fork, as to grab both sides of a slider nub. Helps test for jiggle in unsprung sliders or wafers.

Sometimes called laser track (although many are milled), consists of a continuous cut forming a more or less wiggly line along the blade of the key where the nubs for sliders, wafers or rotors travel and move to their correct positions.

Type of lever typical of italian lever locks. Technically not levers as they don't rotate about one point, but traditionally called so, for they are moved by the key in the same manner, allowing the talon of the bolt to pass through them to open the lock.
Pick profile featuring two rounded waves at the tip, the first one wider and deeper, the other one shallower. Also called C-rake.
Sheet metal between 2 discs or levers that remains stationary, allowing the rotation of one element to not affect adjacent one.
The shaft that the dial is mounted to, which transfers movement to the cam
The groove cut along the spindle.
Small 'key' used to lock the drive cam to the spindle.
A pin shaped like a spool of thread, with wider ends than the middle.
[Spool](/#/glossary?term=spool) driver pin with serrations on the edges of its ends. Also known as a serrated spool.
Short for [Single Pin Picking](/#/glossary?term=single%20pin%20picking).
A lever fence that is pressed towards the wheel pack via spring pressure.
[Sliders](/#/glossary?term=slider) that are subject to spring tension keeping them in place.
Use with top reading dials, leaves only a window from the top from which to read the dial.

Acronym for "Sportsfreunden der Sperrtechnik - Deuchland, e.V.", which liberally translates to "sports fans of barrier technology (fans of locksport) - Germany". It's a german based locksport association, promoting championships, as well as research, science and education projects in locksport. Well known internationally for developing some useful pick designs.
The smaller magic-module size.
Pin which is shaped like a regular cylinder (with a bevel if it is a keypin).
Lock and key where the coded elements can be replaced to change the bitting.
Security driver pin shaped like a 'T'. Provides variable feedback to the picker.
The part of a bolt in a lever lock that slides into the levers when unlocked.
Driver pins in which a few milimeters from one or both extremities, the diameter tapers to a slightly smaller one.
Same as [pin-in-pin](/#/glossary?term=pin-in-pin).
Tool used to apply rotational force to a plug in picking.
The movement of a bolt as the key rotates.
See [top of the keyway](/#/glossary?term=top%20of%20the%20keyway). (2) TOK tensioner: name coloquially given to a tensioner used in the top of the keyway
The nickname for a tensioner used in the top of the keyway. Sometimes just called TOK (see [TOK](/#/glossary?term=TOK))

(Machining) tolerance is defined as the total amount of variation a specific dimension can have from the given value. In locks, we refer to tolerances as the combined variation of, for example, the chamber diameters, or element or parts dimensions, to each other, or relative to the elements they interact with. This variation influences the way the lock binds and works. The better (tighter) the tolerences, the smaller the variation between the element dimensions, usually increasing the difficulty of a pick.

Acronym for "The Open Organisation Of Lockpickers", an international group of lockpicking enthusiasts dedicated to advancing the general public knowledge about locks and lockpicking through teaching, research, and competition. They organize in national groups, and in chapters. Largest and most important national TOOOL groups are in the US, UK and The Netherlands.
Gutting a lock by removing covers or grubs on the bible and emptying pin stacks out from the top of the bible.

The area of the keyway on the same side of the pins in a normal pin-tumbler lock. Is positioned at the top of the lock when the bible is upwards. In regular euro cylinder installation with the bible downwards, it will be the bottom part of the keyway.
Dial is read from above the dial (perpendicular with spindle orientation).

Keypins that have the shape of a torpedo, the key contacting tip resembling the front end of the torpedo, with a reduction in diameter near the opposite extremity, widening just before it contacts the driver pin.
Driver pins resembling a spool driver, bulging at the center.
A pin or sidebar that blocks the rotation of the plug after picking and as one starts to rotate the plug if no key is inserted.
Generally called 'christmas tree drivers', or simply 'trees'; driver pins that look like a spool fused with a gin spool. So called for their simillarity to a christmas tree.
A gate on a tumbler where if the sidebar falls in, it is sufficiently deep for the plug to turn.

TS007 is a technical specification that uses stars and a third party identifier, most commonly the BS [Kitemark](/#/glossary?term=kitemark), to provide a mix and match approach with interchanging cylinders and hardware to achieve a minimum level of security of at least 3 stars. This ensures the installed equipment meets the criteria for protection against the most common methods of attack: drilling, picking, snapping, bumping and plug extraction. Some lock cylinders include TS007 in their model name, demonstrating compliance with this specification.
A moving element on a lock that prevents opening until the correct key is inserted.

Initials for "Underwriters Laboratories", a ratings and standards organization that develops standards for locks, lock cylinders, and associated hardware, such as bolts and latches, based in United States. Present in the face of many locks (example: Medeco Biaxial), identifies safety and security systems and devices that have been certified as meeting those standards of security. In locks, different UL ratings exist, depending on the type of lock.
Underwriters Laboratories certification for key locks.

Underwriters Laboratories certification for combination locks. Divides combination locks between groups according to resistance to unauthorized opening, either into Group 2 or 2M - moderately resistant - or Group 1 (1R if also resistant to radiological attacks) - highly resistant.
Lock without a [curtain](/#/glossary?term=curtain), generally referring to a lever lock.
A lock that is currently in the classification queue, waiting for enough votes to be ranked.

Regular cut in the chamber of a lock, widening the diameter just below the shear line for a short distance, enough to catch the lip of gin spool drivers or xmas tree drivers. Sometimes just called countermilling, although this term is not specific to this type of milling.
A partially set element that is between its resting position and where it needs to be.
Lock that cannot be [gutted](/#/glossary?term=gutting) (disassembled) without destroying the lock and making it inoperable.
[Sliders](/#/glossary?term=slider) that are not subject to spring tension keeping them in place
Describes a lock that is available in different physical formats, such as padlocks as well as door cylinders.
The larger magic-module size.

VdS certification is assigned by VdS Schadenverhütung GmbH, a german based institution specialising in fire protection, security and natural disaster prevention. Among other services, tests security products and certifies them by assigning them to classes which are used by insurance companies and the police. In locks, it's most commonly used for certification of security cabinets, safes, safe locks and strongboxes, but also comercial and residence locking systems and cylinders.

A tumbler shaped like a flat piece of metal, generally found in many mailbox locks. (2) A tumbler that slides in one direction, that is the size of the plug chamber it occupies. At rest it blocks the rotation of the plug by locking into grooves in the lock housing. As the correct key is inserted, it retracts into the plug completely. This definition does not consider the 'wafer-shaped' condition of the tumbler. Although somewhat controversial for that reason, it is the most accepted definition. (3) For some, a subset of sliders that block the rotation of the plug by locking into grooves in the housing. This is also somewhat controversial. (4) A lock that uses wafers as main locking mechanism.
A fixed metalic obstruction inside a lock case used to block the rotation of a blank or a key that was not cut to pass around it. Used in lever or [warded locks](/#/glossary?term=warded%20lock).
A type of lock, the mechanism of which makes use only of [wards](/#/glossary?term=ward). In these, the actuator can be directly reached by the key, blocked by unmoving obstructions.
Protruding metal in a keyway to make picking more difficult and restrict which key shapes can enter the plug.
Similar to the [Bogota](/#/glossary?term=bogota), usually with two to five peaks and/or a more rounded profile.
A round disc with a cut (gate) which determines the correct number for that wheel. Typically there are three wheels, each wheel represents a number in the combination.
When a wheel hides a gate by having a side sitting above a gate, so the gate is never tried by the fence. Usually used when referring to locks with out-of-round wheels.
Steel insert from a windscreen wiper, often used to make tensioners - Or the tensioner made in the shape of such, usually BOK tensioners.
Three peaked wave rake with rounded peaks on both top and bottom.
A tensioner shaped like a Z, with long prongs often used for dimple locks.
When the change index is the same as the dialling index on Key change locks. This requires a mechanism to hold the fence away from the wheels when the lock is in change mode.
Lock that is not yet pinned to a specific bitting. 2) A key not yet cut to a specific bitting. Note that a bitting of '0' will actually be a cut in the blanks of some manufacturers.
